You'll either love it or hate it. It's super grindy but also super addictive, especially if you like survival RPGs. It's got a Skyrim-ish feel to it, but the storytelling/ quests are just meh. It's very challenging to make progress, but when you do, it feels rewarding. Get ready to do a lot of your own research because there is definitely a learning curve in the beginning. The game mechanics aren't always reasonable, but if you just go along with it, you'll have fun.

For example, villagers can't "feed" themselves unless you build a food storage hut or manually refill their home chests. So you could have a whole bunch of food in the fields and they would still literally starve until you've unlocked / built certain buildings. The villagers are really "dumb" and need to be babied. They work really slow and everything in the game happens very slowly. So if you're a fan of instant gratification, this isn't it. Traveling/crafting/unlocking tech tree everything takes a lot of time, points, and patience.

I played the game many times and memorized every mechanism but the problem is that after a while the game does not satisfy you. You have built your village and it is finished. The decoration content is very little, There are no updates to the game as decorations, there should be villagers supported by artificial intelligence. The game has really attracted a lot of attention and these updates should continue.YOU ONLY HAVE 4 LIGHT OPTIONS IN THIS HUGE GAME

Medieval Dynasty is truly a labor of love... Truly.. This is the kind of game that scoops you up, tosses you into a medieval forest, and politely says, “Good luck, peasant..” It’s smooth, it’s beautiful, and it’s so ridiculously deep that I was originally overwhelmed by all the options, but slowly I morphed from confused villager to proud mayor of a thriving dirt-and-thatched-roof empire. I only wish my friends would play it with me, now that co-op exists, but apparently none of them want to spend their nights milking imaginary cows and dying of seasonal allergies in the 13th century. gosh who knew right? The building system is solid but could use more creative freedom..  think less “premade peasant hut” and more “I want to build a house shaped like my hopes and dreams,” With more decor options that make my place pretty. I am a girl after all. think  like in Ark or Conan building. even if it was just for your house and not the premade huts for crafting. They could allow one premade home per user. Hunting is fun but could be a tad more rewarding, because after spearing a boar in the face from ten feet away, I’d like something more than a polite pat on the back. Especially because, dangit bobby that was hard. Still, between the gorgeous environments, the chill vibe, the satisfying village progression, the “raise a dynasty” legacy system, and the feeling of watching your tiny hamlet turn into a full medieval commune of people who hopefully don’t hate you, this game stands strong. It’s charming, it’s cozy, it’s occasionally clunky, have had minimal issues myself,  but it’s absolutely worth diving into..  especially if you enjoy survival, building, and yelling at NPCs who keep complaining about firewood even though you just chopped down half the forest!.

So it would seem I never actually reviewd this game.    Despite owning it for at least 5 years (and early access).

Normally i tend to review games i do *NOT* recommend.     So this might very well be the first time I write a review for a game I recommend.

And boy, do I recommend this.
I'm pretty sure most people know what this game is about, what it looks like etc.  So I'll keep this one short for a change.

There's a bunch of similar games as well,  many of them coming out *after* this game.   And honestly,  NONE of those other games even come *close* to Medieval Dynasty.
The devs,  Render Cube,  have done and are STILL doing an amazing work on this game.
It's SO hard to believe that this is published by Toplitz,  a publisher I wouldn't normally even give 2 cents to.  As most games in their 'catalogue' are either unfinished, or "finished" but buggy and to never be fixed.
But this isn't about the publisher, not really about the devs either for that matter.   But these devs REALLY do deserve to be mentioned.

What , in MY opinion makes this game stand out and WIN against ALL similar games are ..well many things.
For example, but not limited to.
It's "Finished" but they still add cool stuff to the game, and improve existing mechanics.
It nails the immersion,  you just feel..at peace (unless you're in combat) when you walk around in this world.  
Building your own village slowly,  seeing how it went from nothing but a forest, or plains (or w/e),  to a village housing several houses, workshops, and many villagers.
Yes you can build your village almost anywhere. There are obviously some areas you can't build, like too close to another existing village(npc).  
Your villagers feels like actual people. They greet you. They go about their business.  In the mornings or evenings before/after their workday, they might chill out in front of the campfire (if you built on),  and you can interact with them, chat with them.
You also give them work,  for example, one of the villagers might be more fitting for the role of the village's blacksmith. Or cook. Or farmer, etc etc.   They'll go to their workplace,  do whatever it is on the 'todo list'.
You as the player can do basically everything yourself.  You can create fields,  plow, fertilize,  sow,  harvest, etc. Or make tools and weapons at the blacksmith. Or sew new cloths.  And so on.   But why, when you have villagers to assign to these jobs.  So you can focus on whatever it is you wanna do.  
You can roam around the countryside,  maybe find bandit camps,  fight them, loot them.
Go out hunting maybe.  

Oh and dont forget, you gotta get yourself a wife too.   Who will live with you in your house.    After some time, and if you so desire, you can make, and have a baby.    This is true for EVERY villagers btw.   Pair up a male and female in one of the houses you built in your village, and eventually she'll get pregnant.   
As of this writing, there's an upcoming update in about a week,  where they'll change a bit of the mechanic when it comes to pregnant women.   First of all, they'll add so that the pregnancy is actually visible after a season or two.  So you might end up with several female villagers with a preggo belly walking around.
Prior to this upcoming update, they would work til they give birth, then the female will NOT work at all until the kid is of age. Then she'll go back to work, AND the kids can be assigned work to (when they're old enough!)
They can have more than one child as well.

The child that you and your wife make however, is a bit more special.  As he will become your HEIR.   IF and WHEN you die for whatever reason - you can die of age, as everyone ages and dies in this game - you will start playing as your son.  Rinse and repeat, basically.

Few games of this genre has even the "legacy/dynasty" mechanic, where you get married, have a kid, who becomes the heir, and eventually the playable character.    There's a couple of those games, but they are not remotely as well done.
A few games have popped up since MD was released,  but none of them really nails it either.
You have another game from Toplitz,  Wild West Dynasty,  (do NOT buy that sh-t),  a game that they even reworked completely during early access,  which made it a LOT better.   But as of today, there's been months without much or ANY words from those devs.  The game is still lacking content, still has horrible bugs. 
Which again leads to me pointing out, that THESE devs, despite it being Toplitz that publishes it,  these devs really did good work with Medieval Dynasty.

I have NEVER felt more immersed and happy in a game, than I do with MD.    Be it the atmosphere, the birds chirping, or the relaxing fitting music softly playing.
Watching your village grow,  watching your villagers do their daily routine,  watch them start families, watch their and your kids grow up.    Experience the loss of people dying of old age.  
You kinda care about the characters/villagers.   They all have name, and different skills.    Or rather different skills they're good at.

You can take a trip, or ride, to any of the existing (npc) towns,  buy and sell stuff. Or pick up quests.
There's actually a main story in the game as well.  Plus 'sidequests'.
There's SO much in this game, and they keep adding MORE and more.

How can you just not LOVE this game.   I was amazed when I checked the overall reviews here, I was certain this would be one of those 'overwhelmingly positive' games.

This is THE game in this genre.
Many have tried and failed.  Some really new ones that just came out might try to beat MD,  but they are SO early in early access so we wont know for years probably.  Plus most of them do NOT have the whole "get married, start family, have kids, and heir" dynasty-vibe/mechanic.

There's also survival mechanics. Gotta eat and drink etc.
Game year is divded into the four seasons, each season consists of a few days, which you can change when you start a new game.  Think default is like 2 or 3 days.  I.e  2-3 days later it will be next season(spring/summer/fall/winter).  Which also plays in to the immersion, it truly FEELS like autumn or winter.  And you have to plan a rotation for your crops, as they can only be planted certain seasons etc.


Any negatives to be mentioned?  Honestly I can't think of any right now.    I rarely get to say this in my reviews (as I tend to only review games I think people should avoid)  but I f-cking love this game.  
It really IS the best in it's genre, hands down.  No other game even comes close to the scale and scope of this one.
And despite it being published by Toplitz,  it's really effing amazing.

Can't really think of what more I would want in the game.  I wouldnt say no to better graphics. But it looks really great as it is.  I just want the characters to look just a tad better.   But this is literally me nit-picking now.

Good work to the devs.

I love the game, it’s great, I’d definitely recommend it but, it does have its fair share of flaws, glitches, bugs and flat out poor game design in some areas but that could just be me. I also played this game so far entirely in co-op, so all my issues and opinions are completely based off that.

[u][b] Pros [/b][/u]

1. The game is genuinely fun, it looks great and plays pretty well. I love building a village and a community, having an heir and building things up. Watching people age and the seasons pass as the village grows.

2. I love the style to everything, the buildings look great along with all the small decor items you can use.

3. It's simple but i love the "dirtiness" meter, having to wash up here and there, hearing people comments when im dirty and stink, its funny and adds a good bit of immersion. On top of that i like the immersion, what people are saying and talking about, the comments about you, especially the ones where someone is flirting with you, theyre great.

4. I love the amount of references in the game, there's so many. Running around and i hear a guy commenting about a dream he had that referenced the sims. 

5. Romancing someone is really fun. The conversations, the gifts, and the things you can say. Plus i love that they'll clean you up, heal you, or give you something to eat or drink once youre married, small touch but makes things a lot more enjoyable.

[u][b] Cons [/b][/u]

1. Co-op. I'm not sure if it was just me and my gf, but we ran into so many issues. I had several issues on my end but for her the game was constantly breaking. We had to restart our game several times in order to fix things not working properly. 
For example, she would randomly start having items disappear. If she picked it up, unequipped it, whatever it may be, when that glitch happened everything would just start disappearing for her. 
She also has an issue of when shes trying to build something, the parts of the building will just be floating like 30 feet away, so shes hitting nothing on my screen but for her she's building whatever it is. |
Doors for her would absolutely break, if she goes to move a building the door would suddenly freak out. The door wouldnt be in the right spot and would start making extremely loud perpetual screeching sounds.
She would also be unable to interact with crafting and workbenches, it would happen for me to where we couldnt use the well at all anymore and would have to move it.
It'd also just happen randomly where she just couldnt interact with things, such as cut down trees, or picking items up.
Most of these issues only happened to her, so it was really odd and i can only assume it was due to co op.

2. Picking things up is extremely annoying sometimes for seemingly no reason. I would have to spam E over and over then itd eventually pick the item up. So many times id press E, walk away and realize i never picked it up, this happens a lot.
I'm not sure why but it feels like the hit box for picking things up is off as well, so often i have to look way above or below an item to grab it, in both first and 3rd person.

3. Combat. At this point if im fighting people, i only use a bow. Using a melee weapon is way to slow and sluggish so i almost get guaranteed hit every time i swing. Shields are great though, i love using them to tire the enemy out and get away then eventually pull my bow out.
The hit registration feels way off too, several time id hit a deer, moose, or bear in the head or body and just nothing happens like my arrow went into the void. I've tested this many times now, id try shooting something like a deer from as close as i can from its side so its impossible to miss and nothing.
This happens with melee combat too, seemingly if im aiming at the target while theyre running at me i'll miss, but if i swing early it hits most of the time. I use melee for wolves and boar, as they charge i swing early and they run into it.

4. Building. There's an obstacle in the way all the time somehow. You cant destroy rocks, can't terraform, and cant seem to place things exactly how you want. I dont care for my house being on stilts but if theres even a slight incline, my house is put on one. The roads are cosmetic apparently which honestly killed so much of my motivation for wanting to build, customize and decorate a big city. The building is just so finicky, theres rocks every where that you cant get rid of or destroy so they're in the way. It makes no sense and its so annoying when i have completely free space with nothing in the way and i still get the obstacle in the way message. 

4.5. The NPC pathing and Roads. Roads only being cosmetic takes a lot away from the game imo. Makes it where you're almost forced to use the base game roads and bridges and build around that. Unfortunately where we built our village theres a cliff that splits the 2 areas and now people walk all the way around the entire mountain to get to the other side when they could easily take the road we placed but they dont. Forcing us to have to move everything and set it up so the farmers can get to the farms. On top of the that the bridges are also extremely finicky and im not sure if those are just for cosmetic or not but it is such an infuriating task to build a walk way up a hill side. Id absolutely love more creative freedom with building. Like terraforming, removing the rocks, allowing to customize the looks of building like having extra rooms, 2 stories or a porch.

Certain things are shared, certain things aren't. The big well in the middle of my village where I get water doesn't work for them? If some Youtuber didn't tell me a bucket full of creek water kept the new villagers thirst at bay once placed in his chest I would have given up right there. 

You don't really learn anything so you have to buy its schematic. Most games when you discover a bow then you learn how to make it, this game you can have a bow, one you found, but you cannot craft it, you still need to pay for its schematic, the pricing of a lot of goods is a little wonky so you really can't predict if what you are lugging around is worth anything or fractions of a coin so the game ends up being a grind. Medieval Dynasty is ... iffy at best. The game often feels rudderless and directionless. You're task with building a medieval community but to what end? The character interactions are wooden, the combat is woeful and the actual act of building and resource gathering is tedious and uninteresting. I feel like if you're really interested in a medieval life simulation you'd be better off getting Kingdom Come Deliverance 1 or 2.

This game is just pointless grind, not even grind with a reward, just grind

You build your house, you want someone to come live in your village? They want their own house, no sharing
They want water, from the stream beside the village? 
ARE YOU MAD! You need to build a well, oh but... DRINK FROM A WELL????
Nope, need a bucket, so build a workshop.... oh but... bucket needs planks, same workshop? 
HELL NO, different type of workshop
Ok, you got planks, make bucket.... but the bucket needs to be stored.... IN ANOTHER BUILDING, ok build item storage...
Where to store the full buckets of water... item storage? HAHAHHA NOPE
Build another building, food storage, for full buckets of water.
So finally my one villager has water! I only had to build 6 buildings myself to get it....

This is the thing, you think its a game where you get a village to help you - but you basically have to build the whole village yourself before anything works, even when you get villagers one can cut down like 5 logs a day, even basic buildings are 30 logs. This is a tree chopping simulator.

The quests are boring fetch slogs from one side of the map to another with the stamina bar of an elderly athsmatic paraplegic - each year the same quests "re-appear" with the same people...

The game is basically the lest amount of effort it would take to make a game in order to create a video of gameplay to get people to buy it

The one positive point I can think of is the endless, mindless drudgery, chores, backbreaking work and long hours make it possibly the most historically accurate simulation if what it was really like to be a medieval serf
